title: Group including Wilhemina Piper in car, ca. 1910
description: Photos are believed to be taken by Walter F. Piper. According to the 1910 City directory, Piper lived at 1504 18th Ave with his mother Wilhemina and sisters, Matilda and Lillian. The woman in back seat without a hat appears to be Wilhemina Piper based on comparisons to other photos where she is listed as ""Mother." Other individuals unknown.

title: Lizzie [possibly Lillian Piper], ca. 1910
description: Photos are believed to be taken by Walter F. Piper. According to the 1910 City directory, Piper lived at 1504 18th Ave with his mother Wilhemina and sisters, Matilda and Lillian. It is possible that "Lizzie" is Lillian Piper.

title: Seattle City Light Substation at Yesler Way and 7th Ave., ca. 1910
description: Located at 7th Ave. and Yesler Way, this was the city's first substation delivering power to Seattleites. It was constructed in 1910.

title: Switchboard [possibly at Cedar Falls Plant], ca. 1910
description: The location is likely the Cedar Falls Hydroelectric Plant which began supplying Seattle with power in 1905. Interior shots of the same location appear in spl_gpn_172, spl_gpn_173, and spl_gpn_174. The exterior of the Cedar Falls plant is pictured in spl_gpn_176. Signs on the turbines in photos spl_gpn_173 and spl_gpn_174 read ""Plat Iron Works." The June 22, 1912 issue of Pacific Builder and Engineer confirms that the turbines for the Cedar Falls Plant were built by Platt Iron Works.

title: Cedar Falls Hydroelectric Plant, ca. 1910
description: The Cedar Falls Hydroelectric Plant which began supplying Seattle with power in 1905. Interior shots of the plant appear in spl_gpn_172, spl_gpn_173, and spl_gpn_174.

title: Frederick and Nelson baseball team comic, ca. 1913
description: In 1901, a Commercial Baseball League formed in Seattle including employees from various Seattle businesses. Seattle Times, April 19, 1901: "The employees of a number of the leading business houses of the city have held a conference and announce that they will have a commercial baseball league this season. Teams have already been formed in several of the stores and are practicing daily after working hours. Last year there were several store teams and number of first-class games were played between them. A great difficulty was found, however in arranging dates satisfactory to both sides. For this reason several of the more interested players of last year have promoted the league for this year. Their respective employers have consented to allow them a Saturday afternoon occasionally for a game and a committee of the league is at work preparing a regular schedule. A general meeting of the young men will be called in the near future when officers of the associations for the various teams will be elected. The following business houses will be represented: Seattle Hardware Company, Louch, Augustine *Co., Schwabacher Hardware Co., Mitchell, Lewis & Staver, M. Seller & Co., and A. Hambach & Co. It is possible that several more houses will be represented in the league after the project is a little more matured."

title: Turbines [possibly at Cedar Falls Plant], ca. 1910
description: The location is likely the Cedar Falls Hydroelectric Plant which began supplying Seattle with power in 1905. Interior shots of the same location appear in spl_gpn_172, spl_gpn_173, and spl_gpn_174. The exterior of the Cedar Falls plant is pictured in spl_gpn_176. Signs on the turbines in photos spl_gpn_173 and spl_gpn_174 read ""Plat Iron Works." The June 22, 1912 issue of Pacific Builder and Engineer confirms that the turbines for the Cedar Falls Plant were built by Platt Iron Works.

title: Mrs. Hill, ca. 1910
description: Numerous Hills listed in City Directory. Exact identity unknown.

title: Stewart and Holmes Drug Company baseball team, ca. 1913
description: From "The Druggists' Circular and Chemical Gazette," Volume 46, June 1902:" "The wholesale department of the Stewart & Holmes Drug Company, at Seattle, will close on Saturdays at noon during the summer. The employees of the company have a crack baseball team, and the half holiday will give them the opportunity to play." In 1901, a Commercial Baseball League formed in Seattle including employees from various Seattle businesses. Seattle Times, April 19, 1901:""The employees of a number of the leading business houses of the city have held a conference and announce that they will have a commercial baseball league this season. Teams have already been formed in several of the stores and are practicing daily after working hours. Last year there were several store teams and number of first-class games were played between them. A great difficulty was found, however in arranging dates satisfactory to both sides. For this reason several of the more interested players of last year have promoted the league for this year. Their respective employers have consented to allow them a Saturday afternoon occasionally for a game and a committee of the league is at work preparing a regular schedule. A general meeting of the young men will be called in the near future when officers of the associations for the various teams will be elected. The following business houses will be represented: Seattle Hardware Company, Louch, Augustine *Co., Schwabacher Hardware Co., Mitchell, Lewis & Staver, M. Seller & Co., and A. Hambach & Co. It is possible that several more houses will be represented in the league after the project is a little more matured."
subjects: Stewart and Holmes Drug Company (Seattle, Wash.)
Stewart and Holmes Drug Company (Baseball Team)

title: Larkin's Pharmacy baseball team, ca. 1913
description: In 1901, a Commercial Baseball League formed in Seattle including employees from various Seattle businesses. Seattle Times, April 19, 1901: "The employees of a number of the leading business houses of the city have held a conference and announce that they will have a commercial baseball league this season. Teams have already been formed in several of the stores and are practicing daily after working hours. Last year there were several store teams and number of first-class games were played between them. A great difficulty was found, however in arranging dates satisfactory to both sides. For this reason several of the more interested players of last year have promoted the league for this year. Their respective employers have consented to allow them a Saturday afternoon occasionally for a game and a committee of the league is at work preparing a regular schedule. A general meeting of the young men will be called in the near future when officers of the associations for the various teams will be elected. The following business houses will be represented: Seattle Hardware Company, Louch, Augustine *Co., Schwabacher Hardware Co., Mitchell, Lewis & Staver, M. Seller & Co., and A. Hambach & Co. It is possible that several more houses will be represented in the league after the project is a little more matured."

title: Seattle Athletic Club baseball team, ca. 1913
description: From the Seattle Times March 1, 1907 article "Baseball Men Meet Tonight:" "Members of the Seattle Athletic Club who are interested in baseball will need in the club rooms tonight to consider the matter of putting a team in the field this year. Money has already been appropriated  by the directors to buy uniforms and equipment. It is proposed to arrange a schedule of games between the local club and Multnomah and Spokane Athletic Clubs; the University of Washington, the Seattle High School and probably some of the amateur teams in and around the city. The manager of the team will not go outside of the club membership for material. There are so many ball players who, while they are not professionals in the sense that they follow the game as an avocation, still they would have trouble qualifying as amateurs, so no chances will be taken on having men protested. Barry, of last year's football team, is a good ball player; Brown is another man with a good record; Fowler is a clever southpaw, and in fact there is a lot of material that has only to be tried out to give the club a winning aggregation."

title: Banker's Baseball Team, ca. 1913
description: The Seattle Bankers' League included teams from First National Bank, the National Bank of Commerce, the Northwest Trust Company, Seattle National Bank, Union Savings and Peoples Savings Banks, Dexter Horton and Company, Washington Trust Company and American Savings Bank.

title: Stewart and Holmes Drug Company baseball team, ca. 1913
description: The man in the white turtleneck sweater in the middle of the group is William B. Kurtz, a local druggist. From "The Druggists' Circular and Chemical Gazette," Volume 46, June 1902:" "The wholesale department of the Stewart & Holmes Drug Company, at Seattle, will close on Saturdays at noon during the summer. The employees of the company have a crack baseball team, and the half holiday will give them the opportunity to play." In 1901, a Commercial Baseball League formed in Seattle including employees from various Seattle businesses. Seattle Times, April 19, 1901: "The employees of a number of the leading business houses of the city have held a conference and announce that they will have a commercial baseball league this season. Teams have already been formed in several of the stores and are practicing daily after working hours. Last year there were several store teams and number of first-class games were played between them. A great difficulty was found, however in arranging dates satisfactory to both sides. For this reason several of the more interested players of last year have promoted the league for this year. Their respective employers have consented to allow them a Saturday afternoon occasionally for a game and a committee of the league is at work preparing a regular schedule. A general meeting of the young men will be called in the near future when officers of the associations for the various teams will be elected. The following business houses will be represented: Seattle Hardware Company, Louch, Augustine *Co., Schwabacher Hardware Co., Mitchell, Lewis & Staver, M. Seller & Co., and A. Hambach & Co. It is possible that several more houses will be represented in the league after the project is a little more matured."

title: White Knight baseball team, ca. 1913
description: Team named after the White Knight cigar brand.

title: Group of "Nationals," ca. 1913
description: Possibly players on the Snohomish Nationals baseball team.

title: Photographer's portrait [possibly Walter F. Piper], ca. 1910
description: Identity of man may be Walter F. Piper. A caption on the photograph spl_gpn_065 reads "Our house 1504 18th Ave. Seattle, corner view with trees, 1910." In 1910, this address was home to Walter F. Piper, his mother and sisters. Other images of a man identified as the photographer in this collection include spl_gpn_030, spl_gpn_031, and spl_gpn_115. While this photo and the man pictured in spl_gpn_030 and spl_gpn_031 are clearly the same, is not certain if the same individual is also photographed in this image and spl_gpn_115.

title: [Walter F. Piper's] Grandmother, ca. 1910
description: Photos are believed to be taken by Walter F. Piper. Identity of his grandmother unknown.

title: Unidentified woman and girl in snow, ca. 1910
Lincoln High Football Team, ca. 1908
description: The same team appears in the photographs spl_gpn_138, spl_gpn_139 (where it is identified as the Lincoln High team) and spl_gpn_142 (where it is identified as the Washington Athletic Club team.) Consulting the Lincoln High Yearbooks, the team appears to include members from Lincoln High ca. 1908. Based on the photos available in the yearbooks (usually only identified by last name), the people pictured are: Top Row - Coach Allen, "Boo" Bryant, Fred Sparger, Bernard Bliss, Dillard Beck "" Roscoe Pike (biography available in the Lincoln Totem Newsletter, Vol 1., February 1909, pg. 12), Sylliaason, Fallis, Smith, Unknown, Unknown, Unknown, Unknown. Bottom row - Talcott, Ted Terry, Robinson, Unknown, Ben Ohnick.

title: "Kid Quarter," Seattle High School Baseball Player, ca. 1907
description: The player pictured here is also pictured in the 1907 and 1908 Seattle High School Sealth yearbooks but is not identified by name. Seattle High School was the first opened in the city and originally operated on the 3rd floor of the Central School. As Seattle grew and more high schools opened, the name of the school was briefly changed to Washington High School before becoming Broadway in 1908. Known as the Tigers for their orange and black team colors, the Seattle High traveled throughout the United States, gaining national recognition. The 1907 team sent seven players on to play professionally.

title: Colton Football player, ca. 1910
description: Identity of player unknown.

title: William B. Kurtz, ca. 1910
description: The 1910 City Directory lists a William B. Kurtz residing at 3210 41st Ave. SW. His profession is listed as a manager at Lang Drug Co. Kurtz is also shown in spl_gpn_120 with the Stewart and Holmes Drug Company baseball team.
